text:
Hello everyone I’m Ria and in today’s lesson
we’ll talk about some of the funny idioms

that I have come across. Maybe you’ll find
it very very interesting as well. The first

idiom that we’ll talk about is, when pigs
fly. You might hear this a lot, because I

know in some of the television programs or
sometimes when you talk to your friends this

idiom definitely comes about, when pigs fly,
what does it mean? Do pigs actually fly? No

they don’t, it’s a very very funny thought.
A big plump pig flying out somewhere, so when

pigs fly means, something that will never
happen. Given a situation like, for example,

you are talking to your best friend and lets
just put it up in a sentence, if you say that,

Oh!so you hope to become the winner of the
beauty pageant, when pigs fly, so you very

well know that your friend will never be the
winner of the beauty pageant. In the second

situation you might say, you are hoping for
a date with Justin Berber, when pigs fly.

So this is in sarcasm actually, you’re quoting
an incident that will never ever happen. Going

on the second idiom, cats got your tongue,
now this is a funny way of saying things.

Can you ever imagine a cat holding on to your
tongue? It does sound funny, right? This stepped

in the middle ages when witches were being
feared. This was the time when people used

to imagine that witches might come along and
at that point of time, if a witch comes and

you see a witch, just make sure you don’t
report the sighting. The cat of the witch

would hold your tongue. I’m kind of imagining
how that would happen. So I this situation,

if you want to use this idiom, for example,
I’ll give you a very fresh example, if you

walk into a kitchen and at the kitchen counter,
you are seeing your plump cousin sitting very

very oddly suspicious and when you open the
fridge, you have half of the custard pie missing.

Now the first thing that you could say is
what happened to the custard pie?And if he

or she is oddly suspicious, you could always
ask, why are you not answering? Cat got your

tongue. So this is for somebody who is oddly
suspicious, means silent. If somebody is silent

and is not answering to your question that
means cat got his tongue. Now if I think about

years back. In this situation, I was the person
sitting at the counter, feeling oddly suspicious.

My mom used to say, what actually happened
to the custard pie, cat got your tongue? Alright

move on to third one, Bobs your uncle. Who
is bob and why are you calling him my uncle?

This is a very funny idiom, this is to describe
that everything is alright or they you go,

everything is alright or there you go, everything
is fine again. For example, if somebody asks

you for the address of a certain destination
and the person might answer, so you walk up

till the corner of the PA street and turn
to your left and walk towards Godden street,

bobs uncle you are there. Yes that is a very
funny way of saying something like that, but

that is how this was used more in Brittan,
using this idiom, bobs your uncle, means there

you go or if you are making a special recipe,
say add a hint of ginger and two cloves of

garlic and probably bit more spices and bobs
your uncle, your soups done. That is another

way of using that idiom. Now van gogh is music,
van gogh is for music. Now I heard, hope you

know that van gogh was an artist. If for example,
I’ll tell you the meaning of this idiom

later. Let me give you a situation, if you
are playing with a guitar and all of a sudden,

one of your cheekiest friends stands up and
says, Wow! Bravo that was amazing music. Please

don’t be fooled and if he says, my god!!Ria,
you have got van gogh’s ear for music. That

is actually sarcasm. This idiom means that
you are stone deaf. That’s right you are

stone deaf, actually van gogh was an artist,
who was deaf by in one ear, if somebody says,

Wow! You’ve got van gogh’s ear for music
are actually sarcastic. They actually mean

that you have no taste of music that is a
very sarcastic idiom, right? You can use that

for some of your friends, just making fun
of your friends. Now let’s go to the last

one, Pardon my French. This sentence again,
I will give you the meaning later. If you

consider this sentence like monzer, could
you look at that monzer, now do you know what

I think about him? I think that he is a beep,
beep, beep, son of a beep. The only French

word in this statement was monzer. The other
words were not French particularly, in fact

pardon my French means, informal apology 
for swear words. I don’t know, why are we
describing swear words as French? I hope it

is not mean, but this is how the idiom goes
and I have actually heard of people using

it . So putting it in another sentence, you
would say, that girl is very cheeky; she needs

a kick in the beep. The beep is the swear
word and I could always add by saying, please

pardon my French. So that is how we will use
this idiom, pardon my French, is by using

a string of swear words and then you can you
know always add an informal apology by saying,

please pardon my French. Well, that’s all
from me today. I hope that you enjoyed the

lesson and mind you, please do mind you’re
French, Italian, Spanish, all the other words,

etc, etc, etc, till then I’ll see you. Keep
safe and adios, amigos. Take care.
